results.title: 1970s Australian TV miniature
results.credit_line: Designed by Graham McGuffie, Emily Boutard and Megafun
results.brief_description: This gorgeous model miniature celebrates the screen stories Australians loved during the 1970s.

constellations_primary.name: 1970s TV
constellations_primary.description: The 1970s was a thrilling time in Australian television as productions expanded in scale, scope, and ambition.

results.description: David Bowie. Madonna. ABBA. Kylie Minogue. If you were a music act in the 1970s, there was one show you had to be on to solidify your status and that was Countdown. Hosted by Ian ‘Molly’ Meldrum, the ABC program became an institution during its 13-year run. It was the shining jewel in the crown of Australian TV, which moved to exciting new places in the 70s with the arrival of colour. Channel 10 had the saucy Number 96, comedy found new footing with The Aunty Jack Show and the Special Broadcast Service (SBS) was officially launched in 1979 with the aim of telling multicultural Australian stories.
description_for_label: David Bowie. Madonna. ABBA. Kylie Minogue. If you were a music act in the 1970s, there was one show you had to be on to solidify your status and that was Countdown. Hosted by Ian ‘Molly’ Meldrum, the ABC program became an institution during its 13-year run. It was the shining jewel in the crown of Australian TV, which moved to exciting new places in the 70s with the arrival of colour. Channel 10 had the saucy Number 96, comedy found new footing with The Aunty Jack Show and the Special Broadcast Service (SBS) was officially launched in 1979 with the aim of telling multicultural Australian stories.

results.creator_credit: Atlantic Productions, Daniel Grodnik, Bill Badalato and Ernest Thompson
results.brief_description: It was the end of high school and nearing the end of an era when teenage friends Scott (Kiefer Sutherland) and Ralph (Robert Downey Jr) face the full brunt of events in society at the time - the war in Vietnam, Neil Armstrong walking on the moon, and a boom in hippie culture. Scott, a pacifist, has a brother in Vietnam and clashes with his father over his views. Ralph seems to be avoiding the issue through drugs - much to the chagrin of Scott, and Scott’s younger sister, Beth (Winona Ryder), who takes on a bigger role in their lives. In the space of one Summer, two families are drawn together by love, death and war, changing their relationship to one another and society irrevocably. Features a soundtrack of classic 60’s music. Cast also includes Bruce Dern and Mariette Hartley.

results.creator_credit: Clavius Base, Imagine Entertainment (US), Brian Grazer, Ron Howard and Michael Bostick
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “From the earth to the moon”.
In a year marked by anti-Vietnam war prtesets, when Russia seemed ready to send a man to the moon, Frank Borman, Jim Lovell and William Anders prepare for the launch of Apollo 8, the first ever manned voyage to the moon. Their aim is to reach the moon and remain in lunar orbit, the greatest risk is that they have a single engine that must break their orbit if it is to bring them home safely.

results.title: 1960s Australian TV miniature

results.brief_description: This gorgeous model miniature celebrates the screen stories Australians loved during the 1960s.

constellations_primary.name: 1960s television
constellations_primary.description: After its debut in the fifties, Australians rapidly became enthusiastic television viewers in the sixties as American imports started to be mixed with notable local productions.

results.description: The 60s might have been the first full decade of Australian television, but there was a surprising lack of it on the small screen as the local industry began to establish itself. In lieu of the necessary infrastructure, shows from the US dominated due to the low-cost of syndication. This all changed with requirements that commercial TV stations begin broadcasting forty per cent Australian content, which led to the first homegrown drama Consider Your Verdict in 1961. The one-hour program ran for 160 episodes on Channel 7 and ushered in a wave of other seminal Aussie shows like Four Corners and Skippy The Bush Kangaroo.
description_for_label: The 60s might have been the first full decade of Australian television, but there was a surprising lack of it on the small screen as the local industry began to establish itself. results.title: 1960's productions
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, SECV and Shan Benson
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “SEC Documentary films from the period 1950-1993”.
This tape is a compilation of 4 programs: “The Briquette story”: Explains the formation of brown coal and its processing into briquettes at the Yallourn open cut. Using the vehicle of a young couple selecting appropriate heating for their new home. The program outlines the convenience and versatility of briquettes for heating, cooking and hot water generation. The value of briquettes in commercial and industrial usage is also explained. “Valley of power” (prod. writer, Shan Benson): Looks at the importance of the Latrobe Valley, site of the world’s largest single brown coal field, to Victoria. Outlines the economic and lifestyle benefits that the power industry and its supporting infrastructure has brought to the towns of Yallourn, Traralgon, Moe and Morwell. Includes commentary from local identities Willis Connolly, Les Haine, Campbell Husten and Mrs Thompson. “Power makers” (dir. Lee Robinson): Looks at a typical day in the life of four “power makers” - workers at the Yallourn power station. We are shown the important work performed by dredger crews, train drivers, boiler hands, turbine attendants and other tradesmen. Features workers George Fisher, Jack Morris, Rowley Paul and Frank Robertson. “Behind the switch”: Every switch is a demand for instant electricity. The Latrobe Valley brown coal provides four-fifths of electricity. Shows work at Yallourn and Morwell and progress on the new Hazelwood power station. Use of electricity in industry, at home, for transport, and entertainment. Increasing demands are a measure of the State’s growth and rate of development. Emphasis on ability to meet future demands.

results.title: 1956: endangered planet: 1963: picture power: 1954: living longer
results.creator_credit: BBC, WGBH (Boston), Max Whitby, Gabrielle Osrin, James Devinney and Peter Ceresole
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “People’s century: 1900-1999”.
This tape contains episodes seventeen to nineteen of the ‘People’s century 1900-1999’ series. “1959: endangered planet”; post war prosperity had been reached, but at a price. In Minimata, Japan, people become contaminated by mercury poisoning from a nearby factory, while across America pesticides are sprayed on crops to kill insects. Rachel Carson releases the contentious book “Silent Spring”, challenging the notion that pesticide is not harmful. Her novel is only the start of a long and slow process to combat the initial belief that smog, contamination, dirt and pollution are necessary by-products to industrial prosperity. Greenpeace is formed and Environmental Protection agencies established to counteract the balance between people and the environment. Narrated by Sean Barrett. “1963: picture power”; television arrives and brings with it the power of instant communication. Different schools of thought exist internationally as to the potential power of television - public service, political propaganda, or advertising tool. As millions of people across the world began to see the same events unfold at the same time, ultimately entertainment would win out. Narrated by Sean Barrett. “1954: living longer”; the 1950s saw a marked increase in health and wellbeing in developed countries. National Health Services and Social Security were established with a charter of preventative health as well as a concerted effort to try and cure the epidemics which had ailed many, such as polio and tuberculosis. On an international scale the World Health Organisation is established to monitor the health of the world, in particular in developing countries with diseases such as smallpox. With the increased survival rate however came an inevitable by-product of longevity - over population. Narrated by Sean Barrett.

results.creator_credit: BBC, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.) and Chris Granlund
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Changing stages”.
Fourth episode in the six-part series “Changing stages”, written and presented by Richard Eyre, about the history of theatre in the 20th century. In this program we travel back to Britain to a time when British theatre entertained in a fanciful, somewhat straight-laced puritanical manner, appealing to the middle and upper classes through wit and satire. A time during the 1920s and 1930s between the two wars when the audience did not want to be faced with reality and socio-political themes. However, playwrights Noel Coward and Terence Rattigan, through the Royal Court and Comedy Theatres (which were turned into clubs in order to present plays that were banned by the Official Censor, usually for their sexual connotations - homosexuality was considered a “dirty” word in those days), entertained and delighted audiences in the West End with plays such as “The Vortex”, “Private lives” (Coward) and “The Deep blue sea” and “Separate tables” (Rattigan). Rattigan’s plays characteristically expressed repressed emotions and hidden sexual desires smouldering beneath the surface whereas Coward was more out there, hamming it up in such a decadent way as to tease but not shock or disgust his audience. In contrast, following WWII the likes of Rodney Ackland (“The Pink room” 1952), John Osborne (“Look back in anger” 1956), Brendan Behan (“The Quare fellow” 1956) and Shelagh Delaney (“A Taste of honey” 1958) delivered reality and working class attitudes, sexuality and politics in raw and often confronting language taking British theatre in the 1950s on a revolutionary course. John Osborne, known as the “angry young man”, sparked off a whole generation of “angry young men” and a slew of social realist productions but it was the foresight and collaboration of people such as George Devine (Royal Court Theatre manager/producer) and Joan Littlewood (founder of the Theatre Workshop) who guided, supported and propelled the young British playwrights into the limelight and their plays on to the stage. Features excerpts and interviews with actors, playwrights, directors including Alan Bates, John Osborne, Arthur Miller, Peter Hall, Noel Coward, Harold Pinter, Vanessa Redgrave, John Gielgud, Rodney Ackland, Joan Littlewood, Brendan Behan, Tom Stoppard and others. Contains some b&w footage. For more information see www.pbs.org/wnet/changingstages.
results.creator_credit_for_label: BBC, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.) and Chris Granlund

Rattigan’s plays characteristically expressed repressed emotions and hidden sexual desires smouldering beneath the surface whereas Coward was more out there, hamming it up in such a decadent way as to tease but not shock or disgust his audience. In contrast, following WWII the likes of Rodney Ackland (“The Pink room” 1952), John Osborne (“Look back in anger” 1956), Brendan Behan (“The Quare fellow” 1956) and Shelagh Delaney (“A Taste of honey” 1958) delivered reality and working class attitudes, sexuality and politics in raw and often confronting language taking British theatre in the 1950s on a revolutionary course. John Osborne, known as the “angry young man”, sparked off a whole generation of “angry young men” and a slew of social realist productions but it was the foresight and collaboration of people such as George Devine (Royal Court Theatre manager/producer) and Joan Littlewood (founder of the Theatre Workshop) who guided, supported and propelled the young British playwrights into the limelight and their plays on to the stage. Features excerpts and interviews with actors, playwrights, directors including Alan Bates, John Osborne, Arthur Miller, Peter Hall, Noel Coward, Harold Pinter, Vanessa Redgrave, John Gielgud, Rodney Ackland, Joan Littlewood, Brendan Behan, Tom Stoppard and others. Contains some b&w footage. For more information see www.pbs.org/wnet/changingstages.

results.title: 1950s Australian TV miniature
results.credit_line: Designed by Graham McGuffie, Emily Boutard and Megafun
results.brief_description: This gorgeous miniature model celebrates the evolving design of rooms we watch TV in and the birth of TV in Australia.

constellations_primary.name: 1950s television
constellations_primary.description: "Good evening ... and welcome to television." Bruce Gyngell’s famous words launched television in Australia in 1956 on Sydney’s TCN9, with the medium finally arriving in the country towards the later end of the decade.

results.description: “Good evening … and welcome to television.” Those were the famous words of television pioneer Bruce Gyngell that first launched television in Australia in 1956 on Sydney’s TCN9. Experimental transmissions had been taking place as early as 1929. Yet the delay in broadcasting came from heated public debate over what kind of television the nation would have: government-run, like Britain, or commercial, like the US. The result was a uniquely combined service, utilising elements of both. The medium reached the masses just in time for the Melbourne Summer Olympic Games in September.
description_for_label: “Good evening … and welcome to television.” Those were the famous words of television pioneer Bruce Gyngell that first launched television in Australia in 1956 on Sydney’s TCN9. Experimental transmissions had been taking place as early as 1929. Yet the delay in broadcasting came from heated public debate over what kind of television the nation would have: government-run, like Britain, or commercial, like the US. The result was a uniquely combined service, utilising elements of both. The medium reached the masses just in time for the Melbourne Summer Olympic Games in September.

results.title: 1950's volume two
results.creator_credit: Cable Connections Television Ltd and Cyriel van den Hemel
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Rock n’ roll: the greatest years”.
More than any other decade, the 1950’s is synonymous with the rock and roll revolution. This second tape of hits from the 1950’s provides a nostalgic compilation of classics from the era, smattered with a healthy dose of gossip surrounding the performers. Songs on the tape include: “Blue suede shoes”, Elvis Presley: “That’ll be the day”, Buddy Holly: “Ain’t that a shame”, Fats Domino: “Hey Bo Diddley”, Bo Diddley: “Sweet little sixteen”, Chuck Berry: “Bye bye love”, Everly Brothers: “The Great pretender”, The Platters: “Little darlin”, Diamonds: “Cry”, Johnnie Ray: “Rock n roll”, Flamingos: “Singing the blues”, Tommy Steele: “Twenty flight rock”, Vince Taylor: “Gamblin’ man”, Lonnie Donegan: “Baby baby”, Frankie Lymon: “Tutti frutti”, Little Richard: “Oh baby doll”, Chuck Berry: “Oh boy”, Buddy Holly: “All I have to do is dream”, Everly Brothers: “Ooh! My head”, Ritchie Valens: “Baby I don’t care”, Elvis Presley: “Honey chile”, Fats Domino.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Cable Connections Television Ltd and Cyriel van den Hemel

results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Rock n’ roll: the greatest years”.
More than any other decade, the 1950’s is synonymous with the rock and roll revolution. This tape provides a nostalgic compilation of classics from the era, smattered with a healthy dose of gossip surrounding the performers. Songs on the tape include: “Heartbreak hotel”, Elvis Presley: “Problems”, Everly Brothers: “Great balls of fire”, Jerry Lee Lewis: “Lollipop”, Chordettes: “Turn me loose”, Cliff Richard: “Blueberry Hill”, Fats Domino: “Peggy Sue”, Buddy Holly: “Diana”, Paul Anka; “Teenage heaven”, Eddie Cochran: “Shakin’ all over”, Vince Taylor: “Memphis Tennessee”, Chuck Berry: “Blue suede shoes”, Carl Perkins: “Puttin’ on the style”, Lonnie Donegan: “Lucille”, Little Richard: “Please, please, please”, James Brown: “I’m not a juvenile delinquent”, Frankie Lymon: “Yes tonight Josephine”, Johnnie Ray: “Three cool cats”; Cliff Richard, Marty Wilde and Dickie Pride: “Wake up little Suzie”, Everly Brothers: “Only you”, The Platters: “I’m in love again”, Fats Domino: “Don’t be cruel (to a heart that’s true)”, Elvis Presley.
